When maternal effects evolve in the absence of phenotypic plasticity, we find that strong selection favors maternal effects of a substantial magnitude (gray line in Fig. 4D). Interestingly, maternal effects evolve to be large and positive in slowly changing environments, which are characterized by a positive environmental autocorrelation between subsequent generations (Fig. 4 E). By contrast, in rapidly changing environments maternal effects evolve to negative values of a substantial magnitude, again in line with the environmental autocorrelation. To conclude, the strength of phenotypic selection matters considerably to the evolution of maternal effects, as only slight negative maternal effects were found in a corresponding scenario of weak selection (compare gray lines in Fig. 4B and D).
